name: 5-chloro-2-methoxy-4-methylbenzenesulfonyl chloride
Reason: 5-chloro-2-methoxy-4-methylbenzenesulfonyl chloride has a melting point that we can compare to by analyzing its structural components: The basic unit we can compare to is 2-methoxy-4-methylbenzene, which has a melting point of around 100 degrees Celsius. The additional functional groups and structural features in 5-chloro-2-methoxy-4-methylbenzenesulfonyl chloride will affect its melting point: (1) The chlorine atom introduces a significant dipole, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +10 degrees Celsius. (2) The methoxy group introduces additional rigidity and hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius. (3) The methyl group introduces a slight increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at around +2 degrees Celsius. (4) The sulfonyl group introduces a rigid structure and potential for hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius.
